G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the damages claimed do not exceed the jurisdictional threshold for the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 2, 8, as the Defendant operates its business within this judicial district and the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred here.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition for lawful business invitees such as Plaintiff. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The provided passage is a concurrence focused on abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and criticizing continued reliance on trespasser status. It does not state or reaffirm a specific rule that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to maintain premises in a safe condition for business invitees. While the full Mounsey decision is about premises liability duties, this excerpt does not clearly support the specific invitee-duty proposition cited.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant further had a duty to inspect, remedy, or warn invitees of any dangerous conditions of which it knew or should have known. See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe for patrons and to warn them of dangers that are not likely to be known to them but which the defendant knows or ought to know. This aligns with the proposition that the defendant had a duty to inspect, remedy, or warn invitees of dangerous conditions of which it knew or should have known. The entire discussion of constructive notice and time-on-the-floor further presupposes this duty standard.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.” 363 Mass. at 167.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant further had a duty to inspect, remedy, or warn invitees of any dangerous conditions of which it knew or should have known. See Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973); Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states, in its general premises-liability discussion, that a property owner owes lawful visitors (historically, invitees) a duty to use reasonable care, which includes making reasonable efforts to repair or remove dangerous conditions or at least to warn of dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the case focuses on snow-and-ice and abolishing the natural/unnatural distinction, it directly reaffirms the broader duty that encompasses inspection, remedy, and warning duties to invitees. Thus it supports the cited proposition as a statement of general premises-liability duty.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” (Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 371-72.)

Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 5.raw_text: Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 540, 541–42 (1949)
Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 5.proposition: Defendant, by its employees and agents, breached this duty by failing to remedy or warn of a known puddle of spilled milk despite actual knowledge of its existence. See Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 540, 541–42 (1949).
Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s liability for failing to remedy or warn of a *known puddle of spilled milk* with actual knowledge of its existence. Lanagan, however, involves a customer slipping on accumulated, dirty, packed ice on an exterior step, with liability premised on the condition existing long enough that the store had, or should have had, constructive notice. The case does not involve spilled milk, an indoor spill, or an admitted actual knowledge scenario, so it does not support that specific proposition as written.
Lanagan v. Jordan Marsh Co., 324 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “The evidence was sufficient to warrant the jury in finding that the condition of this step as to ice was dangerous for customers of the defendant entering or leaving the store by that entrance, and that this condition had existed for such length of time that the defendant had, or, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have had, knowledge of it. There was, therefore, evidence of the defendant’s negligence.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Defendant’s employee’s acknowledgment that he “had noticed the spill a few minutes ago” constitutes evidence of actual notice. Cf. Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264 (1961).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion never mentions any employee acknowledgment of noticing a spill, nor does it discuss actual notice based on such a statement. Instead, the court finds there was no evidence the defendant’s employees knew of the condition and holds against the plaintiff for failure to prove the spill existed long enough for constructive notice. Thus, Deagle does not support the proposition that an employee’s statement that he noticed a spill a few minutes earlier constitutes evidence of actual notice.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: "There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers."

Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.raw_text: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273, 274–75 (1911)
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.proposition: Alternatively, the condition existed for such a length of time that Defendant should have discovered and corrected it through reasonable inspection, thereby establishing constructive notice. See Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 273, 274–75 (1911).
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.case_name: Anjou v. Boston Elevated Railway Co.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly holds that the condition of the banana peel (dry, gritty, black, and flattened) permitted an inference that it had been on the platform a considerable time, long enough that defendant’s employees, exercising their duty of reasonable inspection, should have discovered and removed it. On that basis, the court finds sufficient evidence of negligence to go to the jury, which is precisely the constructive notice theory described in the proposition.
Anjou v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The inference might have been drawn from the appearance and condition of the banana peel that it had been upon the platform a considerable period of time, in such position that it would have been seen and removed by the employees of the defendant if they had performed their duty. Therefore, there is something on which to base a conclusion that it was not dropped a moment before by a passenger… Hence there was evidence of negligence on the part of the defendant, which should have been submitted to the jury.”

Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264.raw_text: Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264, 266 (1934)
Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act constitutes a breach of its duty to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition in violation of Massachusetts common law. See also Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264, 266 (1934); Batchelder v. Realty Co., 281 Mass. 545, 550 (1933).
Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264.support_reasoning: Mulloy is a contract/assignment case about the meaning and scope of a covenant that an assigned claim is a “just and legal demand.” It does not involve premises liability, duties to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, or any tort-based duty arising under Massachusetts common law. The opinion therefore does not support a proposition about a defendant’s failure to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition constituting a breach of duty.
Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264.relevant_excerpt: “The case at bar is an action on a covenant contained in an assignment to the plaintiff by the Hosmers of a ‘claim and demand’… That covenant, so far as now in controversy, is that ‘said claim is a just and legal demand.’… One purpose of the assignment was to transfer to the plaintiff as assignee the responsibility and expense of prosecuting that lawsuit to its conclusion and to relieve the Hosmers of those burdens.”

Batchelder v. Realty Co., 281 Mass. 545,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act constitutes a breach of its duty to maintain the Premises in a reasonably safe condition in violation of Massachusetts common law. See also Mulloy v. Kay Jewelry Co., 285 Mass. 264, 266 (1934); Batchelder v. Realty Co., 281 Mass. 545, 550 (1933).
Batchelder v. Realty Co., 281 Mass. 545,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns an accounting for rents, the validity and effect of a written agreement under seal, and reaching and applying insurance proceeds. It does not address premises liability, duties to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, or any failure to act constituting a breach of such a duty under Massachusetts common law. Accordingly, it does not support the cited proposition about a duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition.
Batchelder v. Realty Co., 281 Mass. 545,.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff’s bill seeks an account of rents collected for the plaintiff pursuant to a written contract, and to reach and apply any amount found to be due upon a policy of insurance issued by the Mohawk Fire Insurance Company to the individual defendants to payment. … The report shows clearly the existence of valuable consideration for the defendants’ undertaking. As the agreement was under seal, we do not see the materiality of a contention with regard to consideration. The case is not for specific performance.

Janosz v. Berman, 355 Mass. 279, 283 (19.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries. See Janosz v. Berman, 355 Mass. 279, 283 (1969).

Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.raw_text: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 115 (2000)
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were reasonably foreseeable consequences of Defendant’s negligence. See Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 432 Mass. 107, 115 (2000).
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.case_name: Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.support_reasoning: The opinion is an employment discrimination/retaliation decision that deals with liability, evidentiary sufficiency, burdens of proof, jury instructions, punitive damages, and related procedural issues. It does not address negligence, proximate cause, or the foreseeability of damages. The cited page (115) concerns discriminatory animus and differential treatment rather than any discussion of reasonably foreseeable consequences of negligence, so the case does not support the stated tort proposition.
Abramian v. President & Fellows of Harva.relevant_excerpt: There was also evidence that persons similarly situated were treated differently. Abramian was punished more severely than American-born guards for falling asleep on post, being out of uniform, and engaging in assaultive behavior. As noted, the jury could have concluded that it was Carlow who started the fight, and rather than being discharged, as was Abramian, he was promoted. The jury could have found that the treatment of Abramian was motivated by discriminatory animus rather than a legitimate employment decision.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained: a. Medical expenses of approximately $2,000; b. Lost wages of approximately $1,500; c. Pain, suffering, and loss of enjoyment of life; d. All damages permitted by law, including interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Award statutory interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C;
